title: Ticket #4944: New $macro expansion functions for submit
description:
The config/submit macro expander should be extended with functions to allow

  • expanding only parts of a filename
  • expanding an integer with a specified field with (optionally with leading zeros)
  • expanding a substring
  • evaluating integer/real expression at expansion time
  • expanding a single item from a list

new functions

  • $CHOICE(index,listname) or $CHOICE(index,item1,item2,...)
  • $SUBSTR(name,start) or $SUBSTR(name,start,length)
  • $INT(name) or $INT(name,format-specifier)
  • $REAL(name) or $REAL(name,format-specifier)
  • $F[pdnxq](name) or $BASENAME(name) or $DIRNAME(name)

$CHOICE(index,listname)
Expands to the N'th item in $(listname). if $(index) is found, it is expanded and evaluated to determine N, otherwise "index" is evaluated to determine N.

$CHOICE(index,item1,item2,...)
Expands the the N+1'th item in the $CHOICE argument list. if $(index) is found, it is expanded and evaluated to determine N, otherwise "index" is evaluated to determine N.

$SUBSTR(name,start[,length])
Expands $(name) and returns length characters from the string starting with start. if $(start) is found, it is expanded and evaluated otherwise "start" is evaluated. if $(length) is found it is expanded and evaluated, otherwise "length" is evaluated. If start < 0, then start is treated as and offset from the end of the string rather than from the beginning. if length is not specified, the everything from start to the end of the string is returned. if length < 0, then it is added to the actual string length to the the number of characters returned, so $SUBSTR(name,0,-2) returns all but the last 2 characters of the expanded name.

$INT(name[,print-specifier])
If $(name) exists, it is expanded and evaluated, otherwise "name" is evaluated. The resulting long long value is converted to a string using the printf format specifier. If no format is specified "%d" is used.

$REAL(name[,print-specifier])
If $(name) exists, it is expanded and evaluated, otherwise "name" is evaluated. The resulting double value is converted to a string using the printf format specifier. If no format is specified "%.16G" is used. ".0" is appended if the resulting string has no "."

$F[pdnxq](name)
$(name) is expanded, then parsed as a filename and parts are returned based on the characters specified after $F. $BASENAME is the same as $Fnx. $DIRNAME is the same is $Fp. But $Fp is more expressive because the letters can be combined in arbitrary ways.

  • p - print the entire directory portion if any. with trailing /
  • d - print the last segment of the directory if any, with trailing /
  • n - print the filename without extension
  • x - print the file extension including leading .
  • q - print double quotes around the entire output.
